Award.AwardTitle: Precision Phenomenology for LHC Run II : The Standard Model and Beyond
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Ciaran Williams at the State University of New York, University at Buffalo.

The newly upgraded Large Hadron Collider (LHC) represents one of mankind's most technologically advanced and scientifically ambitious projects. By colliding elementary particles against each other at high energies at the LHC, physicists expect to learn about the fundamental building blocks of matter and their interactions at higher energies and smaller distances than have ever been previously explored. The LHC has just begun its second extended data-taking period (Run II), and it is hard to envisage a more exciting time in particle physics. Run II will test whether the recently discovered Higgs boson is fully consistent with our current expectations, or whether it behaves in ways that transcend our best current theories. Another primary aim of the LHC program is to seek a microscopic theory of Dark Matter, which is currently poorly understood, and to understand whether there exist any interactions of Dark Matter with more traditional kinds of matter. Research in this area thus advances the national interest by promoting the progress of science in one of its most fundamental directions: the discovery and understanding of new physical laws. All of these analyses require precise theoretical predictions in order to extract useful information from the data, and Professor Williams will carry out detailed analyses along these lines. Specifically, Professor Williams will perform new calculations using recently developed methods, which will result in a much smaller theoretical uncertainty than those which have previously been used. The results of his calculations will be released publicly to experimental (and theoretical) users and will be utilized in experimental analyses.

More technically, Professor Williams will perform cutting edge calculations at Next-to-Next-to Leading Order accuracy and implement these results into a publicly available computer code, MCFM. The primary focus will be key LHC processes such as diboson production and those related to studies of the Higgs boson. Beyond the Standard Model (BSM) effects will be included, typically in the form of anomalous couplings, allowing for applications in experimental analyses. Prof Williams will also calculate the mixed QCD-EW corrections to vector boson production, and implement the results into MCFM, allowing for an improved measurement of the W boson mass, a crucial parameter in testing the overall consistency of the Standard Model and thereby constraining the possible new physics beyond.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research performed during this award focussed on providing cutting edge theoretical calculations for CERN’s Large Hadron Collider (LHC), located in Geneva Switzerland.  Research in this area advances the national interest by promoting the progress of science in one of its most fundamental directions: the discovery and understanding of new physical laws. Several calculations were completed, and many were released in a public computer code, MCFM. This code is utilized by experimental (and theoretical) particle physicists to compare theoretical predictions to experimental data. During this project there were two areas of particular focus, which corresponds to two types of collisions which occur at the LHC. The first area was the calculation of a class of processes known as color singlets, at Next-to-Next-to Leading Order accuracy, into MCFM. These processes are some of the most common at the LHC, and are therefore crucial to understand in great detail. By extending from Next-to Leading Order accuracy to Next-to-Next-to Leading Order (NNLO), the theoretical errors are significantly reduced, allowing for a much more rigorous comparison of theory and data. These processes were implemented into MCFM and released in the public version of the code. The second main area of research focused on the calculation of a different type of LHC collision, namely the production of a photon at high energy, also at NNLO accuracy. This type of process is more intricate than the color singlet production, and requires great computer power and advanced mathematical techniques to perform. In addition, it represents a very well measured final state, so the need for a precise theoretical prediction to compare to the LHC data is paramount. By completing our calculation we were able to reduce the theoretical uncertainties from around 30% to 5%, which is more inline with the experimental uncertainties. After our initial study we turned our attention to more detailed LHC physics with this final state, including how it can be used to help search for Dark Matter production at the LHC, and other exciting new physics possibilities. We continue to work with this calculation, investigating how it can be utilized to constrain the proton (which is what we collide at the LHC) in greater detail than ever before.

 

In addition to the research described above the project has also resulted in Broader Impacts, specifically in the training of junior researchers. The PI has supervised a postdoctoral researcher, who investigated the production of the Higgs boson at high energies, a new regime which is just beginning to be explored with LHC data. In addition the PI supervised the work of a graduate student, who published a calculation regarding a component needed for the most accurate determination of the mass of the W boson, a critical parameter whose measurement will constrain and test the Standard Model of particle physics in unprecedented detail. Finally the PI supervised three undergraduate students, the PI is pleased to note that two of his students belong to groups traditionally under-represented in the particle physics community.  As a result of their research experience two of the three have since began graduate school, while the third is completing their studies at the University at Buffalo. 

 

The PI notes that this award, originally granted for three years, closed early due to the PI being awarded the CAREER award.
